Polyaniline (PANI) support was doped by acids including HCl acid, 10-camphorsulfonic acid (CSA), thioglycollic acid (TA), and citric acid (CA), to modulate the environment of Au. The catalytic activities refer to the following sequence of Au/CA-PANI > Au/TA-PANI > Au/HCl-PANI ≈ Au/CSA-PANI > Au/EB-PANI toward the 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction. It is found that a less positively charged Au surface can adsorb an appropriate 4-NP molecules and further increase the catalytic performance. The Au/CA-PANI with the lowest positively charged Au surface displayed the highest activity in 4-NP reduction with a reaction rate of 0.035 s−1 and a turnover frequency of 1997 h−1. The electronic state of Au likely played a decisive role for the catalytic activity differences. The readily microchemical environment tuning enabled for the accurate regulation of the electronic state of Au. This work provides a strategy for designing Au catalysts with an accurate electronic state surface. Introduction In the last several decades, polyaniline (PANI) has received numerous scientific interests in many fields such as sensors, batteries, supercapacitors, catalysts, and so on [1,2]. It is inherently conductive due to the π conjugated structures in its molecular chains. PANI is one of the most widely studied owing to its relatively low cost, special doping mechanism, adjustable conductivity, and environmental stability [3]. PANI nanocomposites have become an increasing subject in recent years [4]. Incorporation of a second component in PANI can endow it with enhanced or special properties compared to individual PANI. Multifarious functional materials are introduced in PANI such as graphene oxide [5], carbon nanotubes [6], metal oxides [7], and nanometals [8]. In particular, noble metal nanoparticles (NPs), such as Au, Pd, Pt, and Ag, which are supported on PANI, have received a great deal of attention in the filed of catalysis [2,9–12]. Because of the special chemical/physical structure of PANI, noble nano metals can be loaded on PANI easily by the redox reaction between noble metal precursors and PANI or aniline monomer [2,12], or by the adsorption between PANI and noble metal NPs [8,9]. And the catalytic performance including activity and stability is usually enhanced due to the interaction between the PANI support and the noble metal active sites. Gold was historically considered inert in chemical reactions before the 1980s. Then the revolutionary works of Hutchings [13] and Haruta [14] on gold catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination and CO oxidation open the door to gold catalysis. Due to the excellent low temperature activity and superb catalytic selectivity, gold catalysts have been developed in various catalytic reactions, such as CO oxidation [15], oxidative esterification [16], propene epoxidation [17], hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds [18] and so on. One of the most important key factors for the catalytic performance of Au NPs are supporting materials. They can influence the size, shape, chemical state, and active sites of Au NPs. A perfect supporting material can endow small-sized Au NPs highly dispersed with more exposed active sites. The supported materials reported for Au NPs are mainly metal oxides [19], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [20], and polymers [2,9]. Recently, Au NPs loaded on PANI have been research hotspots in gold catalysis. As a conductive polymer, PANI not only favors the electron transfer between the active sites and reactants but also endows the Au NPs highly dispersed with the help of N heteroatom in polymer chains [21]. Afsahi et al. synthesized Au nanocatalysts supported on PANI with a magnetic core. PANI here played the role of stabilizing Au NPs and acting as the conductive shell to incorporate the magnetic core. Excellent performance in azo dyes reduction was found after 8 times reuse due to the effective anchoring effect of PANI [22]. Mondal and co-workers prepared water-soluble Au-PANI nanocomposites and also confirmed their high rate of catalytic performance for dye degradation (Congo red and methylene blue) [23]. Dai et al. found that PANI could significantly promote the CO oxidation in favor of the electron transfer between TiO2 and Au NPs [24]. Usually, in gold catalysts, Au NPs are the active sites, and their size and chemical state can remarkably influence the catalytic performance. In the Au/PANI system, the conductive PANI support has doping/dedoping properties. Therefore, it is possible to change the electrons in the PANI chains through doping or de-doping engineering to regulate the chemical state of Au NPs. In our previous work, we found that the imine sites (=N + H-) of doped PANI favored Au NPs stability [25,26]. The chemical state of metallic Au NPs could be changed to positively charged or negatively charged with different acid doping. However, the doping effect was not studied systematically. And no works have focused on the doping effect on the catalytic performance of Au/PANI. Therefore, regulation of the PANI structure to adjust the catalytic performance through doping engineering is of great concern. The aim of this work is to provide a systematic evaluation of the catalytic performance of doped PANI-supported Au catalysts. We demonstrate that the kind of doping agent in PANI changes the microchemical environment of Au NPs. And by virtue of the electronic metal support interaction (EMSI) between Au and support, the electronic state of Au NPs can be modulated. Through the electronic state tuning, the catalytic performance can be enhanced. The catalyst is very stable and effective for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP). This work can provide new insights for catalyst design with an accurate electronic state of Au and will promote the precise preparation of the necessary Au catalysts in the industry. Experimental Chemicals Aniline, 4-nitrophenol, 10-camphorsulfonic acid (C10H16O4S), sodium borohydride, thioglycollic acid (C2H4O2S), and hydrochloric acid (36 wt%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Corporation. Ammonia water (25 wt%) was acquired from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Corporation. All chemicals in this work were used as received. Preparation of emeraldine base PANI The emeraldine base PANI (EB-PANI) was prepared according to a previous study by aniline polymerization and deprotonated with ammonia. [27]. In brief, 0.18 g ammonium persulfate and 0.3 mL aniline were, respectively, dissolved in 10 mL of HCl solutions (1.0 M) in two flasks separately. The two newly prepared solutions were mixed quickly and sonicated for 30 s to make the mixture uniform. The mixture was left static for 2 h in a dark place. The obtained product was purified with water and deprotonated with ammonium hydroxide (0.1 M). The EB-PANI was finally purified and dried for 12 h at 60 °C. Preparation of PANI doped with different acid doping In this paper, various acids, such as HCl, 10-camphorsulfonic acid (CSA), thioglycollic acid (TA), and citric acid (CA), were used as PANI doping acid. In the case of TA-doped PANI, 0.1 g of EB-PANI was dispersed in 20 mL of TA solution (1.0 M) and was stirred at room temperature for 6 h. The obtained product was purified, dried, and denoted as TA-PANI. All other acid-doped PANI were prepared by the same procedure and were denoted as HCl-PANI, CSA-PANI, and CA-PANI, respectively. Preparation of AU/PANI catalysts The Au NPs were loaded on the acid-doped PANI supports through the adsorption method. The Au sol was freshly self-made according to our previous study [28]. The acid-doped PANI was dispersed in the freshly prepared Au sol and was stirred slowly for 24 h. The samples were washed and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. According to different PANI support, the Au/PANI catalysts were denoted as Au/HCl-PANI, Au/CSA-PANI, Au/TA-PANI, and Au/CA-PANI, respectively. The theoretical loading amount of Au NPs in all Au/PANI catalysts was adjusted to 0.5 wt% in preparation. Au/EB-PANI was also prepared for comparison under the same condition. Characterization The samples morphology was analyzed by SEM (JEOL 7900F) and TEM (Tecnai G2 F30). The Au NPs size distribution was given by counting more than 200 Au particles through the TEM images. XPS (ESCALAB250) was performed to confirm the elemental composition and the surface chemical states. Specific surface areas were measured using a surface area analyzer (ASAP 2020 HD88). The actual Au content in the catalysts was obtained by ICP-AES. FTIR spectra were recorded using an FT-IR spectrometer (VERTEX 70). XRD spectra were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2500 diffractometer operating with Cu Kα radiation. A UV–vis spectrophotometer was performed to monitor the change of 4-NP concentration in the catalytic reaction. Catalytic evaluation The catalytic reduction of 4-NP was used to test the catalytic behavior of Au/PANI catalysts. 0.17 g of NaBH4, 5.5 mL of 4-NP (5.43 × 10−3 M) and 3.15 × 10−2 g of catalysts were mixed and stirred in a flask. During the reaction, at a certain time interval, 0.5 mL solution was extracted from the reaction by pipette and filtered by an injector equipped with a filter. The filtrate was diluted to 5 mL and characterized by a UV–Vis. The adsorption equilibrium of 4-NP without NaBH4 was carried out under the same conditions except that the adsorbent was 0.01 g. Results and discussion The preparation processes of acid doped PANI and the corresponding Au catalysts were illustrated in Scheme 1 . PANI was prepared with ammonium persulfate as the oxidant and HCl acid as the dopant. Then it was dedoping by ammonia to prepare EB-PANI. After doping with different acids, Au NPs were loaded on the doped PANI by Au sol adsorption. The special dedoping/doping properties of PANI favored the preparation of Au catalysts, which were supported on different acid doped PANI carrier. The FTIR spectra of different kinds of PANI are shown in Fig. 1 a. In terms of EB-PANI, the characteristic peaks are higher and sharper than those of the doped forms [29]. Peaks at 1589, 1496, 1379, 1302 and 1165 cm−1 can be assigned to quinonoid (Q) stretching (N=Q=N), the benzenoid (B) stretching (N-B-N), CN stretching in QBQ, CN stretching for secondary aromatic amine and the peaks for CH in Q=NH.+-B or B-NH.+-B, respectively. Compared with EB-PANI, the peaks of acid-doped PANI shift to low wavenumbers (Table S1), especially for the peaks at 1165 and 1589 cm−1, which implies the doping effect of acids in PANI and the B-Q ring transitions due to acid protonation, respectively [26,29]. Therefore, those peak shifts towards lower wave numbers are the signature of successful acid doping [30]. The new peak at 1656 cm−1 appears in TA-PANI, corresponding to the C=O stretching in TA dopant [31]. The peaks at 1734 and 1036 cm−1 in the CSA-PANI spectrum are related to the carbonyl vibration and the sulfonic group in the CSA dopant [32,33]. The above results indicate the successful doping of PANI. The FTIR spectra of Au/EB-PANI and acid doped Au/PANI are presented in Fig. 1b. The peaks at 1589, 1496, 1379, 1302, and 1165 cm−1 of EB-PANI are slightly shifted to 1591, 1499, 1381, 1304, and 1165 cm−1 in Au/EB-PANI. The slight shifts between them indicate the interaction between Au NPs and PANI. It is known that the heteroatoms in polymer, such as N, S, and O, have lone pair electrons, which can act as anchoring sites to stabilize noble metals [34,35]. Detailed data of the characteristic peaks of acid-doped PANI-supported Au catalysts are shown in Table S2. Compared with Table S1, most of the characteristic peaks of Au/PANI doped with acids slightly shift to high wavenumbers after gold loading. Because of the low loading amount of Au NPs, the shift is slight (some of them are close to the monitoring limit). However, the shifts of N=Q=N are more obvious, which may give evidence for the interaction between Au NPs and -N=C- in the PANI chain [25,26]. Fig. 2 shows the UV–vis spectra of PANI and the corresponding catalysts after Au loading. As shown in Fig. 2a, the peak centered at 333 nm in the spectra of EB-PANI corresponds to the π-π* transition in PANI. The peak at 660 nm is due to the excitonic transition from benzenoid to quinonoid, which confirms the de-doped state of the EB-PANI [36]. In Fig. 2a, three characteristic bands are observed in PANI doped with different acids. The band around 320∼360 nm corresponds to the π-π* transition within the benzenoid rings. Bands at about 400∼420 nm and a long tail at a wavelength around or longer than 800 nm are related to the doping level and the polaron formation, respectively, indicating that the PANI supports are doped [37]. The two bands around 320∼360 and 400∼420 nm are distorted as a single peak or combined into a flat between 360 and 420 nm, as shown in Fig. 2a [27]. After Au loading, the long tail around or longer than 800 nm shifts to a high wavelength for all products. The interaction of Au NPs with PANI is confirmed by a combination of UV analysis and FTIR analysis. XRD patterns of EB-PANI and acid doped PANI with the corresponding Au catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . As shown in Fig. 3a, a broad peak centered at 20.2° associates with the parallel face-to-face π-π stacking of PANI chains [38]. In the acid-doped PANI samples, a new peak around 25.1° is observed, which is caused by the interaction of counterions during doping with protons near the N atoms of the PANI chain [39]. The counterions offer a necessary electrostatic forces to induce the higher chain ordering degree in PANI [38]. No differences are observed after Au NPs adsorption in Fig. 3b. And no obvious peaks of Au NPs are found in all catalysts, indicating the low concentration or the high dispersion of small Au NPs on PANI [40] The SEM images depicting the morphology of PANI are shown in Figs. 4 and S1. From Fig. 4a, it can be observed that EB-PANI has a rod-like structure with a diameter around 98 nm due to the PANI fibrillar growth. The diameter changes to 114 nm in HCl-PANI due to acid doping process, which significantly affects the morphology of PANI [41]. As discussed above, the counterions introduced during acid-doping processes provide the necessary electrostatic forces, which induce the rearrangement of PANI chains. As shown in Figs. 4c, S1a, and S1b, organic acid-doped PANI results in different morphology. They are more compact and more aggregated with irregular shaped morphology [42]. Compared with inorganic protonic acid, organic acids, such as CA, CSA, and TA, are large in volume. As doped counterions, they seem to lead the PANI chains more randomly to form irregularly shaped aggregates. The detailed morphology of Au/EB-PANI and Au NPs supported on PANI doped with different acids was investigated by TEM. In this work, Au catalysts supported on PANI were prepared by Au sol adsorption. The TEM image of Au sol showed spherical-shaped Au NPs with an average diameter of 3.96 ± 0.89 nm, mainly in 2–5 nm (Fig. S2). Due to the bad dispersion of PANI, all PANI products aggregate together, as shown in Figs. 5 and S3. Small black dots in diameter around 2 to 5 nm can be found in all PANI-supported catalysts, indicating a good dispersion of Au on PANI supports. Fig. 5d shows the HRTEM image of Au/CA-PANI. Highly dispersed Au NPs with spherical shapes are clearly observed on the CA-PANI support. The exposed lattice fringes with spacings 0.24 nm are attributed to Au (111), confirming the successful load of Au. In addition, according to the analysis of XRD above, there are no obvious peaks of Au in all PANI-supported catalysts, which also confirms the well-dispersed Au NPs on PANI. Even without the organic ligand protection, the Au NPs maintained a well-defined spherical shape in a highly dispersed state, indicating that an interaction exists between the Au and PANI support that facilitates immobilization and stabilization of Au. The catalytic properties of doped PANI-supported Au catalysts along with the Au/EB-PANI for the 4-NP reduction were studied to explore the acid doping effect of PANI on the catalytic reaction. As shown in Fig. S4a, 4-NP shows a characteristic peak at 317 nm. After the introduction of excessive NaBH4, it shifts to 400 nm due to the 4-nitrophenolate ions formation [43]. The absorbance of 4-NP with NaBH4 at 400 nm decreases with decreasing 4-NP concentration (Fig. S4b). The relationship between them was expressed by the linear equation (Fig. S4c). Fig. S4d shows that the 4-NP reduction with NaBH4 in the absence of a catalyst does not occur for 12 h. However, in Fig. 6 a, Au/CA-PANI shows drastic catalytic activity, and the 4-NP reduction is completed within 130 s. The new peak of 4-AP at 300 nm is observed. As shown in Fig. S5, it takes about 140, 140, 210, and 200 s for the 4-NP reduction over Au/TA-PANI, Au/HCl-PANI, Au/CSA-PANI, and Au/EB-PANI, respectively. The 4-NP reduction can be considered a pseudo-first-order reaction due to the excessive NaBH4 compared with 4-NP. The reaction rate k and the turnover frequency (TOF) (calculated at t = 60 s) can be given by the following equation: (1) L n C t C 0 = L n A t A 0 = − k t (2) TOF = n 4 − NP × Conversio n 4 − NP n Au × t = n 4 − NP × M Au × ( A 0 − A t ) W Catalysts × wt % × t × A 0 where At/A0 and Ct/C0 are the 4-NP absorbance and concentration ratio at time t and 0, n4NP and nAu are the molar numbers of 4-NP and Au during the catalytic reaction, MAu and wt% are the molar weight and actual loading amount of Au. Relations of Ln(Ct/C0) versus t with gold catalysts are shown in Fig. 6b. The orders of catalytic activity for 4-NP reduction based on Fig. 6b is Au/CA-PANI > Au/TA-PANI > Au/HCl-PANI ≈ Au/CSA-PANI > Au/EB-PANI. A comparison of the catalytic performance of Au catalysts based on the results of Fig. 6b is summarized in Table 1 . The reaction rate constant k and the TOF of Au/CA-PANI are 0.035 s−1 and 1997 h−1, both of them are the best among all catalysts prepared. The rate constant per unit of Au (k’) was calculated based on the actual amount of Au loading shown in Table 2 . The order of k’ is the same as the order of k. And the k’ of Au/CA-PANI is 223.79 s−1 g Au−1. In Table 2, we can see that the load of Au of all catalysts are nearly equal to the preparation amount of 0.5 %, indicating that the PANI support can effectively adsorb Au NPs [44]. It is also an evidence for the interaction between PANI and Au, which facilitates the adsorption and stabilization of Au NPs. The textural parameters of different PANI supports were estimated by N2 adsorption measurements. As shown in Fig. S6, all samples have similar type IV characteristics, indicating the mesoporous nature of materials. EB-PANI and CA-PANI possess higher N2 adsorptions, demonstrating their high pore volume (0.25 and 0.21 cm3/g). The textural properties in Table 2 of CA-PANI were 40.2 m2/g (surface area), 0.21 cm3/g (pore volume), and 24.8 nm (mean pore diameter). All properties of CA-PANI are not the highest among all samples. Furthermore, from Table 2, it can be found that after acid doping, the BET surface area values of all doped PANI are lower compared with EB-PANI, also confirming again the rearrangement of the PANI chains during doping processes. The order of surface area is EB-PANI > CA-PANI > HCl-PANI > TA-PANI ≈ CSA-PANI, obviously differing from the catalytic performance order. Thus, the surface area here is not the main factor for the enhancement of catalytic activities. Usually, the catalytic activities of Au are affected by the loading amount, the size, the surface electronic state, and the metal-support interaction (MSI) [45,46]. In this work, we study the surface electronic state of Au NPs in the catalysts by a control variate method. The loading amount of Au is set at 0.5 wt%, and all Au NPs are absorbed on PANI supports (Table 2). In Figs. 5 and S3, the Au size distributions are almost the same. Therefore, the surface electronic state of Au may play an important role in the catalytic performance enhancement. XPS was performed to confirm the electrostates of Au and the interaction between Au and PANI supports. As shown in Fig. S7, the XPS shows that the catalyst surfaces are composed of Au, C, and N, indicating the successful Au load in all catalysts. The presence of S and O in catalysts confirms the acid doping of PANI. The Au 4f high-resolution spectra for Au-supported PANI catalysts are shown in Figs. 7 and S8. As we all know, the Au 4f7/2 binding energy (BE) of metallic Au0, Au+, and Au3+ is at 84.0, 84.6, and 85.9 eV, respectively [26]. As shown in Figs. 7 and S8, the BE of Au 4f7/2 for PANI-supported Au catalysts are 84.15, 84.20, 84.20, 84.30, and 84.35 eV for Au/CA-PANI, Au/TA-PANI, Au/CSA-PANI, Au/HCl-PANI, and Au/EB-PANI, respectively. Compared with the BE of Au0 at 84.0 eV, the BE shift of all catalysts indicates a strong EMSI [47]. This strong interaction between Au and PANI would be one of the factors that allowed almost all Au NPs to be deposited on PANI (Table 2). Curve fittings of Au 4f7/2 of Au/EB-PANI show that the ratio of Au0 and Au+ is 40.83 and 59.17 % with the peaks centered at 84.10 and 84.46 eV, respectively. However, for Au/CA-PANI, the ratio of Au0 and Au+ is 58.40 and 41.60 % with the peaks centered at 84.10 and 84.45 eV. Table S3 summarizes the quantification and identification of Au species on the Au NPs surface. Due to electron transfer between Au to PANI, the Au NPs surface is charged positively (Au+), indicating that the surface electronic state of Au can be adjusted by modulating the microenvironment around Au NPs through doping engineering of PANI supports. Compared with 84.0 eV of metallic Au, the order of BE shift of Au 4f7/2 is Au/CA-PANI (0.15 eV) < Au/TA-PANI (0.20 eV) = Au/CSA-PANI (0.20 eV) < Au/HCl-PANI (0.30 eV) < Au/EB-PANI (0.35 eV), which coincides with the opposite order of catalytic performance, except for Au/CSA-PANI. Thus, compared to Au/EB-PANI, the acid doping process results in electron transfer from the PANI support to the Au NPs, resulting in a less positive Au NPs surface. As is known to all, the dopant can change the structure of PANI [27,48]. The reversible doping and dedoping characteristics favor the regulation of PANI structures [49,50]. As a conductive polymer, PANI can favor electron transfer during the catalytic reaction. The structure of Au/PANI doped with HA acid (A presents the conjugated base of HA) is shown in Fig. 8 . After acid doping, the imine nitrogens are protonated. The positively charged imine nitrogens are balanced by counterions [51]. It was reported that the electronic surface state of Au could be adjusted through the interaction between Au and the -N= of PANI [21,44,52]. The microenvironment of noble metals influenced their electronic state. H.-L. Jiang et al. demonstrated that functional groups on UiO-66-X modulated the Au25 electronic state. The various functional groups changed the modulated microenvironment around the Au25 sites and regulated the Au electron state, which finally dominated the catalytic performance [53]. The surface microenvironment of Pd was reported to be easily modulated by functional group and metal substitution in MOFs, finally regulating the electronic state of Pd and then modulating the catalytic activity [54]. Therefore, the doping process of PANI here regulates the microenvironment of Au and adjusts its electronic state in a similar way to MOF. To better understand the interaction between PANI and Au, the XPS for N 1 s of Au/EB-PANI and Au/CA-PANI are shown in Fig. 9 . From Fig. 9a, the N 1 s of Au/EB-PANI can be deconvoluted into four peaks at 401.78, 399.68, 399.11, and 398.35 eV, which are assigned to -NH2 +-, =NH+-, -NH- and =N-, respectively. After CA acid doping, the BE of =NH+- and =N- shift to high binding energies (399.87 and 398.59 eV), which indicates a decrease in the electron density of imine nitrogens [55]. Therefore, changes of chemical microenvironment of Au NPs by doping engineering lead to electron transfer from imine nitrogens to Au, as confirmed by the XPS spectra of Au 4f. Therefore, the BE shift of Au 4f7/2 of Au/CA-PANI is 0.15 eV, lower compared with Au/EB-PANI. More details of N1s XPS spectra of PANI-supported Au catalysts are shown in Fig. S9 and Table S4. The order of the total ratio of imine nitrogens (=NH+- and =N-) is Au/CA-PANI (62.9 %) > Au/CSA-PANI (61.52 %) ≈ Au/TA-PANI (61.13 %) > Au/HCl-PANI (58.81 %) > Au/EB-PANI (57.81 %), which is well correlated with the order of BE shift of Au 4f7/2 mentioned above, confirming again the interaction between Au and PANI and the electron transfer from imine nitrogens to Au. As shown in Fig. S10a, the ratio of quinoid and benzenoid (Iq /Ib ) for EB-PANI (0.951) decreases after CA doping (0.913) due to the formation of polysemiquinone radical cationic state. After loading of Au, the Iq /Ib changes due to interaction of Au and the support (Fig. S10b). It should be noted that the Iq /Ib of Au/CA-PANI (0.924) is higher than that of Au/EB-PANI (0.884), indicating the higher quinoid structure in Au/CA-PANI. The electron transfer from CA-PANI to Au leads to the increase of the content of quinoid. The result is in good agreement with the XPS, which confirms the higher content of imine nitrogens in Au/CA-PANI. Therefore, combined with the XPS and FTIR results, we confirms the interaction and the electron transfer between Au and imine nitrogens. Therefore, by doping engineering, the chemical microenvironment of Au NPs is changed, which modulates the electronic state of Au NPs surface with the aid of interaction between Au and the imine nitrogens of PANI. As mentioned above, the load and the size distribution of Au for all catalysts are almost the same. And the surface area is not related to the catalytic activities. In catalytic processes, the reactant first needs to be absorbed on the surface of the catalysts. If no reductant is added, an adsorption balance of 4-NP will be established on catalyst surface. The Δabsorbance (average value) in Fig. 10 reflects the mean amount of 4-NP adsorption on the catalyst surface. The Δabsorbance of EB-PANI and CA-PANI is 0.0543 and 0.1440, respectively, confirming that after acid doping, the surface properties of PANI are changed, as analyzed in Fig. 4 and Table 2. However, the Δabsorbance of Au/EB-PANI and Au/CA-PANI is 0.0700 and 0.1474, which is increased by 0.0157 and 0.0034, respectively, indicating that the load of active Au NPs favors the increase of 4-NP adsorption. In the aforementioned XPS analysis, we know that the electronic state of Au NPs surface is modulated by the acid doping process. In comparison with Au/EB-PANI, the surface of Au NPs in Au/CA-PANI is less positive due to the electron transfer from the imine nitrogens of PANI to Au NPs. Generally, Au NPs with positively charged surface can facilitate the adsorption of 4-NP molecules [26,56]. And as everyone knows, an appropriate adsorption of reactants is suitable for the good performance of catalysts because that the high adsorption means the hard desorption after the reaction, which is adverse for the catalytic reaction. Thus, after acid doping by CA, the surface state of Au NPs can be tuned and the less positive Au NPs can realize the appropriate adsorption of 4-NP molecules and further improve the catalytic performance. To further confirm the importance of the surface electronic state of Au in the catalytic reaction, Au/CA-PANI (0.5 M) (acid-doped by CA at a concentration of 0.5 M) was prepared for comparison. As shown in Fig. S11, Table S3, and S4, the total ratio of imine nitrogens of Au/CA-PANI (0.5 M) is 59.35 %, which is lower than that of Au/CA-PANI (62.9 %). Thus, after acid doping with low CA concentration, less electronics are transferred from the imine nitrogens to the Au surface, leading to a lower imine nitrogen content and a more positive Au surface (BE 84.20 eV, Table S3 and Fig. S11b). Fig. 11 a and b show that the Δabsorbance of CA-PANI (0.5 M) and Au/CA-PANI (0.5 M) is 0.0948 and 0.1118, which is increased by 0.017 after gold loading. The k of Au/CA-PANI (0.5 M) is 0.028, which is lower than that of Au/CA-PANI (0.035). Thus, compared with Fig. 10c and d, we again confirm that the positive Au surface favor the adsorption of 4-NP. By doping engineering, the microchemical environment can be changed and the electronic state of Au surface can be adjusted. The surface state of Au affects the adsorption of 4-NP. An appropriate adsorption of 4-NP is necessary for the enhancement of catalytic activities. A summary of the BE shift of Au 4f7/2 and the reaction rate k of all catalysts are shown in Fig. 12 . After three parallel experiments, for the catalysts Au/EB-PANI, Au/HCl-PANI, Au/TA-PANI, and Au/CA-PANI, the repeatability of the reaction rate of every catalyst is good and it increases with a decrease in the BE shift of Au 4f7/2. Therefore, it can be summarized that doping engineering can tune the chemical microenvironment of Au and the electronic state of Au, resulting in less positive Au NPs being beneficial in 4-NP reduction. Fig. 12 shows a good correlation between the BE shift of Au 4f7/2 and the catalytic activity, but Au/CSA-PANI shows different results than expected. The Δabsorbance of Au/CSA-PANI increases by 0.0126 after loading active Au NPs with positively charged surface (Fig. S12), between the Au/EB-PANI (0.0157) and Au/CA-PANI (0.0034) as expected. Thus, to investigate the cause of the low activity of Au/CSA-PANI, comparative experiments were performed. Fig. S13 shows that the conversion of 4-NP is not completed even after 180 s when Au/CA-PANI is used by adding sodium camphorsulfonate to the reaction solution, which is lower than the conversion of Au/CA-PANI (130 s, Fig. 6a) without camphorsulfonate. Since the reducing agent NaBH4 is excessive, sodium cations would have no negative effect on the catalytic properties. Therefore, camphorsulfonate ions would hinder the catalytic reaction in the case of Au/CSA-PANI. A comparison of the catalytic activity in the reduction of 4-NP for Au/CA-PANI and reported data of Au-based catalysts is shown in Table 3 . The catalytic performance of Au/CA-PANI is higher than that of PANI(Microtubes)/Au, [25] Fe3O4@Au-PANI, [57] PANI@magnetic graphene oxide/Au, [58] and polystyrene/PANI/Au [43] due to the relatively small size of Au NPs. And it is also good compared with Au/Al2O3, [59] indicating the advantages of CA-PANI support. The catalytic performance of PANI(Spindle-shaped)/Au (prepared as the same as the Au/CA-PANI except for the different support) is lower, [28] compared with that of Au/CA-PANI. Therefore, the doping processes indeed enhance the catalytic activities of PANI supported Au catalysts. The reusability results of Au/CA-PANI are shown in Fig. 13 . The reaction time was kept as 60 s to avoid the full conversion and the initial conversion was 93.5 %. After each cycle, the catalysts were separated, washed and dried at 60 °C overnight. Fig. 13 shows that the 4-NP conversion declines only 34.2 % even after ten cycles, suggesting the excellent stability of Au/CA-PANI. Fig. 13b shows that the Au NPs in the used catalyst still maintain the spherical structures, indicating the good stability of Au on PANI due to the EMSI. Combined with the Au size distribution, we know that a small quantity of Au NPs aggregate to some extent, and the size of Au increases slightly (2∼7 nm) with an average diameter around 4.88 nm. The XPS spectra and the quantification and identification of Au and N species of Au/CA-PANI after ten circles reused are shown in Fig. S14 and Table S3 and S4. Compared the fresh prepared Au/CA-PANI (Au0 58.40 %, Au+ 41.60 %), the content of Au0 and Au+ for the reused Au/CA-PANI is 48.48 and 51.52 %, respectively. And the content of imine nitrogens of the reused Au/CA-PANI is 55.65 %, which is lower than that of Au/CA-PANI (62.9 %). The lower imine nitrogen content and a more positive Au surface of reused catalysts lead to the slight decrease of catalytic performance. Therefore, the slight aggregation and the changes of the electronic state of Au NPs possibly give the reason for the mild decline of 4-NP conversion. As shown in Fig. S15, the average k of fresh prepared Au/CA-PANI is increased linearly with the increase of the catalyst dosage. And the k’ is almost the same, confirming again that the Au NPs are the active sites. As shown in Fig. S15b, the mean value of k remains stable in the pH range of 2 ∼ 10, indicating the good adaptability of our catalysts. Therefore, the Au/CA-PANI is proved to be robust in the 4-NP reduction. 4-NP, as a toxic contaminant, exists extensively in wastewater. The reduction product 4-aminophenol (4-AP) is relatively non-toxic with good biocompatibility and is important for the production of antipyretic drugs. To confirm the feasibility of the catalyst in actual wastewater treatment, we performed the catalytic reduction of 4-NP using Au/CA-PANI with different inorganic salts or organics. In Fig. 14 a, with increasing NaNO3 concentration, the reaction rate k first increases and then decreases. Appropriate amounts of NaNO3 would promote electron transfer and enhance catalytic performance, although excessive NaNO3 would adsorb on catalyst and cover active sites, leading to poor catalytic activities [44]. The highest k (0.048 s−1) is obtained at 0.146 M NaNO3, which is 100 times the 4-NP concentration. It should be noted that even if the concentration of NaNO3 is 1.46 M, 1000 times of 4-NP, the k is almost equal to the reaction rate without NaNO3, indicating the wide adaptability of Au/CA-PANI. In Fig. 14b, apart from Na3PO4, which leads to the inactivation of catalysts, Au/CA-PANI shows good adaptability with various inorganic salts or organics such as NaCl, KCl, Na2SO4, Na2S2O3, glucose (C6H12O6) and urea (CH4N2O). Therefore, Au/CA-PANI would have promising potential for the 4-NP treatment in industrial wastewater. The strategy for modulating the electronic state of Au is described in Scheme 2 . By virtue of the special doped/de-doped properties of PANI, the EB-PANI is re-doped by different acids to help fine-tune the microchemical environment around Au NPs. After acid doping, the imine nitrogens are protonated to form positively charged imine nitrogens, which are balanced by counterions (A −). The different A − ions during the doping of PANI with different HA acids alter the chemical environment of Au. Due to the strong EMSI between Au NPs and the imine nitrogens of PANI, the surface electronic state of Au can be delicately tuned. A widely accepted catalytic mechanism involves three stages [44,60,61]. First, the reducing agent BH4 −and the reactant 4-NP (deprotonated) are adsorbed reversibly on catalyst surface. Meanwhile, active Au-H sites are formed due to the BH4 −dissociation. Then the electrons and hydrogen atoms are transferred from Au NPs to 4-NP, which leads to the efficient conversion of 4-NP to 4-AP. Finally, the product 4-AP is desorbed from the active Au sites. It has been known from the above adsorption experiments that positively Au surface can adsorb more 4-NP molecules [26,56]. By doping with different acids, the chemical environment of Au can be changed. And the surface electronic state of Au can be modulated in favor of EMSI between Au and PANI. The less positive Au NPs can realize the appropriate adsorption of 4-NP molecules and further improve the catalytic performance. Conclusions In this work, Au NPs with uniform size are deposited on PANI support, which creates a modulated chemical microenvironment for Au sites based on doping engineering. The doping process changes the microchemical environment of Au NPs and modulates their surface electronic state by the EMSI between the imine nitrogens of PANI and Au. Remarkably, the activities of catalysts with different electronic states of Au are distinguishable. They give the catalytic activity order of Au/CA-PANI > Au/TA-PANI > Au/HCl-PANI ≈ Au/CSA-PANI > Au/EB-PANI. The different electronic states of Au in Au/PANI, attributed to the change of the microenvironment of Au, are responsible for the above results. Through electronic state tuning, it was confirmed that the less positive charged Au can adsorb the appropriate amount of 4-NP molecules and further increase the catalytic performance. The Au/CA-PANI with the lowest positively charged Au surface displayed the highest activity in 4-NP reduction with k of 0.035 s−1 and the TOF of 1997 h−1. The catalyst is very stable, effective with good adaptability for the reduction of 4-NP. This work highlights the effect of the Au electronic state and provides a new idea for the design of catalysts with an accurate electronic state of Au. The insights of this work will promote the precise preparation of the necessary Au catalysts in the industry. coredata.dc:description: Polyaniline (PANI) support was doped by acids including HCl acid, 10-camphorsulfonic acid (CSA), thioglycollic acid (TA), and citric acid (CA), to modulate the environment of Au. The catalytic activities refer to the following sequence of Au/CA-PANI > Au/TA-PANI > Au/HCl-PANI ≈ Au/CSA-PANI > Au/EB-PANI toward the 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction. It is found that a less positively charged Au surface can adsorb an appropriate 4-NP molecules and further increase the catalytic performance. The Au/CA-PANI with the lowest positively charged Au surface displayed the highest activity in 4-NP reduction with a reaction rate of 0.035 s−1 and a turnover frequency of 1997 h−1. The electronic state of Au likely played a decisive role for the catalytic activity differences. The readily microchemical environment tuning enabled for the accurate regulation of the electronic state of Au. This work provides a strategy for designing Au catalysts with an accurate electronic state surface.
coredata.dc:title: Manipulation of the electronic state of Au to boost the catalytic efficiency of Au/polyaniline by doping engineering
